Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Expanding the Structural Complexity and Functional Repertoire of Sequence-Specific Polyamide Oligomers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports Professor Amelia Fuller of Santa Clara University, for the synthesis and physiochemical analyses of peptoid and extended peptoid polyamides using bound solvatochromic dyes and biarsenical fluorophores. The goals of this research are to understand intramolecular assembly as a function of peptoid structure, and to discover new peptoids with tertiary and quaternary structure. Screening of efficiently synthesized peptoid libraries will lead to rapid evaluation of both inter- and intra molecular association events, allowing facile identification of motifs leading to higher-order structures. Molecules showing interesting association and folding properties will be used for drug discovery studies through a public online database (D3).

Broader impacts of the research include opportunities for undergraduate students to get involved in research in organic synthesis, combinatorial screening methods, and even anti-microbial activity testing in a microbiology laboratory. Professor Fuller has created a unique opportunity at her institution to integrate her research activities directly into both chemistry and biology teaching environments during the academic year. In addition to yearlong research projects, independent summer projects are also planned.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research carried out during the award period (2011-2017) addressed the study of molecules that emulate biomolecules’ structures. Although biomolecules have an exquisitely diverse repertoire of roles in nature, they typically only function in a narrow set of conditions (temperature, pH, concentration, solvent composition). Thus, work to design, prepare and study putative surrogates for these biomolecules that function in a wider range of conditions is an important priority. These biomolecule-emulating compounds could be used to engineer new molecules with utility in a range of fields, including as catalysts, sensors, and sequestrants.

During this award period, the PI and her undergraduate research assistants pursued a research objective to advance fundamental understanding of the molecular features that are important for the structure of a class of peptide-mimicking molecules called peptoids. Peptoids emulate the structures of peptides, but their structures tend to be more robust to changes in temperature, pH, and, to some extent, solvent composition. The PI and her assistants synthesized dozens of new molecules and used advanced spectroscopic techniques to evaluate their structural features. To highlight one vignette from this research, peptoids that self-associate in aqueous solution were identified; this feature approaches some of the structural features identified in natural systems. Since this discovery, the PI has used this peptoid to study its interaction at surfaces, which will be important for future applications of peptoids as coatings for biomedical devices. The PI has also applied this peptoid as a receptor for a highly toxic molecule formed in carbon combustion processes. These applications underscore the promise for broad utility of molecules discovered and studied in the PI’s laboratory. The PI has disseminated the findings from this work in five research articles and several presentations at national and international scientific conferences.

Also during this award period, the PI pursued an educational objective of training dozens of undergraduates in research skills to prepare them to contribute to the STEM workforce. To this end, the PI designed laboratory experiments that engaged students in the preparation of new molecules that have potential utility to inhibit bacterial growth and thus to serve as drug leads. Although no active molecules were identified, numerous students received training. The PI had disseminated the outcomes of these educational efforts in one publication, two book chapters, and several presentations at national and international conferences.
